Net worth is a measure of your financial health. It\'s calculated by subtracting your total liabilities (what you owe) from your total assets (what you own).

Assets include:
- Liquid assets (cash, savings, current accounts)
- Investment assets (stocks, bonds, mutual funds, real estate investments)
- Retirement assets (pension funds, retirement savings accounts)
- Personal assets (home, car, valuables, business assets)

Liabilities include:
- Short-term debts (credit cards, personal loans, outstanding bills)
- Long-term debts (mortgages, business loans, vehicle loans)

For example, if you have %1$s50,000,000 in assets and %1$s20,000,000 in liabilities, your net worth is %1$s30,000,000.

A positive net worth means you own more than you owe, which is a sign of financial stability. Tracking your net worth over time helps you measure your financial progress and make informed decisions about your money.

A home loan (mortgage) is used to purchase property. The property itself serves as security for the loan, meaning the lender can repossess if you fail to make repayments.

How it works: When you take out a mortgage, you borrow money to buy a property and repay it over a set period (usually 15-25 years) through monthly payments. Each payment includes:
- Principal: The amount borrowed
- Interest: The cost of borrowing
- Property Tax: Annual land use charge or ground rent
- Insurance: Property insurance
- Legal Fees: Registration and documentation costs

For example, if you buy a home for %1$s30,000,000 with a %1$s6,000,000 deposit, you\'ll borrow %1$s24,000,000. At a 15%% interest rate over 20 years, your monthly repayment will be approximately %1$s320,000.

A tax calculator helps you estimate your income tax liability based on your income, tax status, and reliefs. This helps you plan your finances and understand your take-home pay.

How it works: Enter your annual income, tax status, and any reliefs or allowances. The calculator estimates your tax liability using Nigerian tax bands (PAYE) and shows your effective tax rate.

For example, if you earn %1$s6,000,000 annually with standard reliefs, your estimated income tax (PAYE) would be based on the progressive tax rates up to 24%% for higher earners.
